action.action-desc: Mr. Gottheimer (for himself and Mr. Fitzpatrick) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend the Safe Drinking Water Act to establish deadlines for promulgation of national primary drinking water regulations for certain contaminants, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Lead Free Schools Act of 2017.
Section 1412(b)(2) of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300g–1(b)(2)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: Notwithstanding any other deadline established in this subsection, not later than 9 months after the date of enactment of the Lead Free Schools Act of 2017, the Administrator shall issue revised national primary drinking water regulations for lead and copper.
The revised regulations issued under clause (i) shall ensure that—

subclause.text: corrosion controls are reevaluated anytime source water or treatment is changed;
test results are valid, by prohibiting techniques that artificially lower lead levels, including flushing before samples are taken;
monitoring includes school sites for all public water systems serving schools (as defined in section 1461);

notification of lead problems is clear and effective, including, to the extent practicable, notification, at least annually, of any testing and such problems at school sites on the Internet website of the applicable local educational agency; and
lead service lines are fully replaced on a set timetable and whenever contamination is detected.

clause.header: Scope of lead line replacement requirements
clause.text: Requirements to replace lead service lines under the revised regulations issued under clause (i) shall extend to all service lines controlled by public water systems, regardless of ownership.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding any other deadline established in this subsection, not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of the Lead Free Schools Act of 2017, the Administrator shall publish a maximum contaminant level goal and promulgate a national primary drinking water regulation for perfluorinated compounds.

Notwithstanding any other deadline established in this subsection, not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of the Lead Free Schools Act of 2017, the Administrator shall make a determination, pursuant to paragraph (1)(B)(ii), on whether to regulate 1,4-dioxane under this section.

subsection.text: Section 1401 of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300f) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The term lead service line means a pipe and its fittings, which are not lead free (as defined in section 1417(d)), that connect the drinking water main to the building inlet.

subsection.text: Section 1459B(a) of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300j–19b(a)) is amended by striking paragraph (4).

section.header: Competitive grant pilot program for drinking water fountain replacement for schools

subsection.text: Part F of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300j–21 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Competitive grant pilot program for drinking water fountain replacement for schools

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this section, the Administrator shall establish a competitive pilot grant program to provide assistance to local educational agencies for the replacement of drinking water fountains manufactured prior to 1988.
Funds awarded under the competitive pilot grant program—

paragraph.text: shall be used to pay the costs of replacement of drinking water fountains in schools; and
shall be awarded on a competitive basis, as determined by the Administrator.

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section not more than $5,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2018 through 2022.
Section 1461(5) of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300j–21(5)) is amended by inserting or drinking water fountain after water cooler each place it appears.

section.text: Section 1464(d)(7) of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300j–24(d)(7)) is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking 2017 through 2021 and inserting 2018 through 2022.
